<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">We report the synthesis, magnetic studies and EPR characterization of five heterometallic {Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>}, where M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ba, Mn, Co, Ni, and Zn complexes containing dinuclear chromium units {Cr(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cr} as a “magnetic brick”. In the Mn(II) complex, a bridging function is performed by a carboxylate oxygen atom of the nitrilotriacetate ligand that leads to the formation of a trinuclear complex. The magnetic interactions present in these complexes have been deduced from analyses of the magnetic data and full line shapes of the EPR spectra.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

We report the synthesis, magnetic studies and EPR characterization of five heterometallic {Cr2MII}, where M=Ba, Mn, Co, Ni, and Zn complexes containing dinuclear chromium units {Cr(OH)2Cr} as a "magnetic brick". In the Mn(II) complex, a bridging function is performed by a carboxylate oxygen atom of the nitrilotriacetate ligand that leads to the formation of a trinuclear complex. The magnetic interactions present in these complexes have been deduced from analyses of the magnetic data and full line shapes of the EPR spectra.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Five heterometallic compounds with formulae [Ba(H2O)4Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]⋅3H2O (I), [M(bpy)2(H2O)2] [Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O, where M2+ =Zn, (II); Ni, (III); Co, (IV) and [Mn(H2O)3(bpy)Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅(bpy)⋅5H2O (V); bpy =2,2'-bipyridine, (nta =nitrilotriacetate ion) have been prepared by reaction of I with the corresponding MII-sulfates in the presence of 2,2'-bipyridine. Substances I-V have been characterized by magnetic susceptibility measurements, EPR and X-ray determinations. I represents a 2D coordination polymer formed by coordination of centrosymmetrical dimeric chromium(III) units and Barium cations. The 10-coordinate Ba polyhedron is completed by four water molecules. Compounds II-IV are isostructural and consist of non-centrosymmetric dimeric anions [Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]2-, complex cations [MII(bpy)2(H2O)2]2+ and solvate water molecules. The octahedral coordination of chromium atoms implies four donor atoms of the nta 3- ligands and two bridging OH groups. Multiple hydrogen bonds of coordinated and solvate water molecules link anions and cations in a 3D network. A similar [Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]2- unit is found in V. The bridging function is performed by a carboxylate oxygen atom of the nta ligand that leads to the formation of a trinuclear complex [Mn(bpy)(H2O)2Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]. Experimental and calculated frequency and temperature dependences of EPR spectra of these compounds are presented. The fine structure appearing on the EPR spectra of compound V is analyzed in detail at different temperatures. It is established that the main part of the EPR signals is due to the transitions in the spin states of a spin multiplet with S =2. Analyses of experimental and calculated spectra confirm the absence of interaction between metal ions (MII) and Cr-dimers in complexes III and IV and the presence of weak Mn-Cr interactions in V. The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities for I-V was fitted on the basis of the expression derived from isotropic Hamiltonian including a bi-quadratic exchange term.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since a long time ago  investigation of the structures and properties of hydroxo Cr(III) complexes has been stimulated by interest in the building of versatile clusters along with the study of correlations between structural parameters and strength of magnetic coupling . A number of chromium(III) dimers [Cr2(μ-OH)2L x ] y  with a bis-μ-hydroxo bridge, where L is a bidentate or polydentate ligands have been investigated from this point of view. For this type of dimers Hoffmann and co-workers  have characterized the exchange coupling constant J as a sum of ferromagnetic (J f) and antiferomagnetic (J af) terms J = J af + J f which can be correlated to structural parameters .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">By now, dimeric units are used as building blocks to find new synthetic routes giving supramolecular architectures with interesting, magnetic, optical, and electric or catalytic properties . Recently, we have studied the structure and geometric contributions to the magnetic interactions in heterometallic dinuclear chromium(III) complexes with Mg, Ca, Sr, and Ba ions containing dihydroxo bridging units and nitrilotriacetate ligand . Using the dinuclear chromium(III) units we have built different 0D, 2D and 3D systems. As a continuation of this work we report here the synthesis, structure and magnetic investigation of five new heterometallic compounds made with the similar “magnetic brick” units formulated as [Ba(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>), [M(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O where M<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Zn, (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>); Ni, (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>); Co, (<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>) and [Mn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>V</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By now, dimeric units are used as building blocks to find new synthetic routes giving supramolecular architectures with interesting, magnetic, optical, and electric or catalytic properties . Recently, we have studied the structure and geometric contributions to the magnetic interactions in heterometallic dinuclear chromium(III) complexes with Mg, Ca, Sr, and Ba ions containing dihydroxo bridging units and nitrilotriacetate ligand . Using the dinuclear chromium(III) units we have built different 0D, 2D and 3D systems. As a continuation of this work we report here the synthesis, structure and magnetic investigation of five new heterometallic compounds made with the similar "magnetic brick" units formulated as [Ba(H2O)4Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]⋅3H2O (I), [M(bpy)2(H2O)2] [Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O where M2+ =Zn, (II); Ni, (III); Co, (IV) and [Mn(H2O)3(bpy)Cr2(OH)2(nta)2](bpy)⋅5H2O (V).

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All starting materials and solvents were purchased from Aldrich and were used without further purification.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a GX system 2000 Perkin–Elmer spectrophotometer. Magnetic susceptibility data (2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) were collected on powdered samples of a SQUID-based sample magnetometer on Quantum Design model MPMS instrument in a 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>T applied magnetic field. All data were corrected for diamagnetism of the ligands estimated from Pascal’s constants . Magnetic data analyses were carried out with the nonlinear least-squares fitting using the program <ce:small-caps>visualiseur</ce:small-caps>-<ce:small-caps>optimiseur</ce:small-caps> for Matlab<ce:sup loc="post">®</ce:sup>
. EPR investigations were carried out with use of X- and Q-bands E-12 Varian and ERS-230 radiospectrometers in a wide temperature range.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

All starting materials and solvents were purchased from Aldrich and were used without further purification.

Physical measurements

The IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a GX system 2000 Perkin-Elmer spectrophotometer. Magnetic susceptibility data (2-300K) were collected on powdered samples of a SQUID-based sample magnetometer on Quantum Design model MPMS instrument in a 0.1T applied magnetic field. All data were corrected for diamagnetism of the ligands estimated from Pascal's constants . Magnetic data analyses were carried out with the nonlinear least-squares fitting using the program visualiseur-optimiseur for Matlab® . EPR investigations were carried out with use of X- and Q-bands E-12 Varian and ERS-230 radiospectrometers in a wide temperature range.

<ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>[Barium-di-<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>-hydroxy-bis-(nitrilotriacetatochromium(III))]heptahydrate [Ba(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(nta)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Water (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was added to a mixture of <ce:italic>H</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic> (0.76<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and dispersed BaCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (1.18<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). The resulting solution was warmed up to 95<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. After complete dissolution of BaCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CrCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) dissolved in 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of water was added to the initial solution, the temperature being maintained at about 95<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Neutralisation of the reaction mixture (pH 6.5–7) was carried out with concentrated NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>OH. The solution changed from violet to navy blue-green. The reaction mixture was filtered off and concentrated to 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL. Twenty-four hours later, the blue-violet crystals were separated by filtration, washed with cold water, ethanol and ether. Yield: 95%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[Barium-di-μ-hydroxy-bis-(nitrilotriacetatochromium(III))]heptahydrate [Ba(H2O)4Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]⋅3H2O (I)

Water (100mL) was added to a mixture of H 3 nta (0.76g, 4mmol) and dispersed BaCO3 (1.18g, 6mmol). The resulting solution was warmed up to 95°C. After complete dissolution of BaCO3, CrCl3 ⋅6H2O (1.07g, 4mmol) dissolved in 50mL of water was added to the initial solution, the temperature being maintained at about 95°C. Neutralisation of the reaction mixture (pH 6.5-7) was carried out with concentrated NH4OH. The solution changed from violet to navy blue-green. The reaction mixture was filtered off and concentrated to 30mL. Twenty-four hours later, the blue-violet crystals were separated by filtration, washed with cold water, ethanol and ether. Yield: 95%.

elements.clean_text:
[Di-(α,α'-bipyridyl)-diaqua-zinc] [di-μ-hydroxy-bis-(nitrilotriacetatochromate(III))heptahydrate, [Zn(bpy)2(H2O)2] [Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O (II)

ZnSO4 ⋅7H2O (0.28g, 1mmol) and α,α'-bipyridyl (0.32g, 2mmol) were dissolved in 30mL of water. After addition of crystalline BaCr2(nta)2(OH)2 ⋅7H2O (0.76g, 1mmol) the resulting solution was warmed up to 40-50°C. Then the cold solution was filtered to eliminate BaSO4 and concentrated to 20mL. Twenty-four hours later the violet crystals that appeared were separated by filtration, washed with cold water, ethanol and diethyl ether. Yield: 62%. The syntheses of [Ni(bpy)2(H2O)2][Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O (III), [Co(bpy)2(H2O)2][Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O (IV), [Mn(H2O)3(bpy)Cr2(OH)2(nta)2](bpy)⋅5H2O (V) compounds are analogous to that described for II. Details of IR spectra and analytical data are reported in the .

<ce:para view="all">Substances <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>V</ce:bold> are soluble in water and DMSO, DMF; insoluble in methanol, ethanol, acetone and diethyl ether.</ce:para><ce:section-title>X-ray experimental part</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The X-ray data were collected on a STOE Imaging Plate Diffractometer System (IPDS) equipped with an Oxford Cryosystems cooler device using a graphite monochromator (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Data were collected  using <ce:italic>φ</ce:italic> rotation movement with the crystal-to-detector distance equal to 70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm (<ce:italic>φ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0–270°, Δ<ce:italic>φ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.5° for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>; <ce:italic>φ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0–200°, Δ<ce:italic>φ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2° for <ce:bold>V</ce:bold>). All the structures were solved by direct methods using <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>-97  and refined by full-matrix least-squares on <mml:math altimg="si3.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:msubsup>

<mml:mi>F</mml:mi>

</mml:mrow>
</mml:math> with <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-97  with anisotropic displacement parameters for non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions (C–H 0.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and they were included in the refinement in the riding-model approximation with <ce:italic>U</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">iso</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text:
Substances I-V are soluble in water and DMSO, DMF; insoluble in methanol, ethanol, acetone and diethyl ether.

X-ray experimental part

The X-ray data were collected on a STOE Imaging Plate Diffractometer System (IPDS) equipped with an Oxford Cryosystems cooler device using a graphite monochromator (λ =0.71073Å). Data were collected  using φ rotation movement with the crystal-to-detector distance equal to 70mm (φ =0.0-270°, Δφ =1.5° for I, II, III, and IV; φ =0.0-200°, Δφ =2° for V). All the structures were solved by direct methods using shelxs-97  and refined by full-matrix least-squares on     F   o   2     with shelxl-97  with anisotropic displacement parameters for non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions (C-H 0.96Å) and they were included in the refinement in the riding-model approximation with U iso =1.1U (atom of attachment). Positional parameters of the H(water) atoms were obtained from difference Fourier syntheses and verified by the geometric parameters of the corresponding hydrogen bonds. Scattering factors were taken from the standard compilation . The molecular plots were obtained by using the zortep program . The absorption corrections were introduced by semi-empirical methods based on equivalent reflections, using the program multiscan . The final full-matrix least-squares refinement, minimizing       ∑ w ( |   F   o   2   | - |   F   c   2   | ) 2     2    , converged at the values of R and wR listed in  , together with the main crystallographic parameters.

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Barium complexes <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> have been prepared by the interaction of CrCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and Ba<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The reaction proceeds smoothly in aqueous solution and the pH was adjusted with concentrated solutions of NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>OH. Series of the heterometallic Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M compounds, M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Zn, (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>) Ni, (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>); Co, (<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>); Mn, (<ce:bold>V</ce:bold>), were prepared by exchange reaction between [{Ba(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}{Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>) and sulfate of bivalent metals (MSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) in water solutions containing bipyridine ligands. Comparative analyses of their IR spectra with the starting barium compound [{Ba(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}{Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O indicate the presence of similar bands corresponding to the dinuclear chromium dihydroxo units. Asymmetric ν<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) and symmetric ν<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>(COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) stretching carboxylate frequencies are separated by 220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, suggesting monodentate coordination. The large absorption bands in the 3600–2800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region are attributed to ν(OH) vibrations of water molecules involved in hydrogen bonds. Characteristic frequencies for bipyridine ligands are also present in the IR spectra of compounds <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>. Eventually, the IR data suggest that complexes <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> are very similar and different from complex <ce:bold>V</ce:bold> which must present another composition and structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Barium complexes I have been prepared by the interaction of CrCl3 ⋅6H2O and Ba3(nta)2. The reaction proceeds smoothly in aqueous solution and the pH was adjusted with concentrated solutions of NH4OH. Series of the heterometallic Cr2M compounds, M=Zn, (II) Ni, (III); Co, (IV); Mn, (V), were prepared by exchange reaction between [{Ba(H2O)4}{Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2}]⋅3H2O (I) and sulfate of bivalent metals (MSO4) in water solutions containing bipyridine ligands. Comparative analyses of their IR spectra with the starting barium compound [{Ba(H2O)4}{Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2}]⋅3H2O indicate the presence of similar bands corresponding to the dinuclear chromium dihydroxo units. Asymmetric νas(COO-) and symmetric νs(COO-) stretching carboxylate frequencies are separated by 220cm-1, suggesting monodentate coordination. The large absorption bands in the 3600-2800cm-1 region are attributed to ν(OH) vibrations of water molecules involved in hydrogen bonds. Characteristic frequencies for bipyridine ligands are also present in the IR spectra of compounds II-IV. Eventually, the IR data suggest that complexes II-IV are very similar and different from complex V which must present another composition and structure.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Based on the crystal structures, the complexes <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>V</ce:bold> have been divided into two groups, which differ by the structural function of the [Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dimeric anionic building block. In the first group (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>V</ce:bold>) the Cr(III) dimer acts as a ligand with different denticities. The isostructural compounds <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> belong to the second group characterized by ionic structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Based on the crystal structures, the complexes I-V have been divided into two groups, which differ by the structural function of the [Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]2- dimeric anionic building block. In the first group (I and V) the Cr(III) dimer acts as a ligand with different denticities. The isostructural compounds II-IV belong to the second group characterized by ionic structures.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The structural determination of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> indicates that it is a 2D coordination polymer. The asymmetric part of the unit cell contains two crystallographically independent centrosymmetric dimeric anions (denoted as A and B, respectively). Two fragments of the crystal structure showing the A and B dimeric units are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor> while selected bond lengths are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. The octahedral chromium centre is linked to four donor atoms of the <ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands (<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>) and two bridging OH groups. The Cr–N bonds in <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> are equal to 2.067(5), for A and 2.071(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for B dimers, the Cr–O ones being in the 1.875(4) and 1.956(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å range. The coordinated nitrilotriacetic acid forms three five-membered chelate rings (R, G1 and G2) according to Ref. . The Cr⋯Cr separation in A and B dimers are equal to 2.879(2) and 2.888(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Dimers A (a) are characterized by four <ce:italic>G</ce:italic>-carboxylate groups chelating the 10-coordinate Ba ions. Two of them are tridentate-bridging groups (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and two are tetradentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). In contrast, the B-type dimers (b) contain two <ce:italic>trans G</ce:italic>-carboxylate bridging groups (η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). The barium coordination sphere is made of six oxygen atoms coming from four <ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands and four water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl3"></ce:float-anchor>). The carboxylate oxygen atom O6 bridges two centrosymmetrically related Ba<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>ions, with a Ba⋯Ba separation of 4.855(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The decadentate dimeric anions (A) lead to the formation of chains along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis, while the Cr2-dimers (B) join the adjacent chains into a 2D polymeric structure (), which is additionally stabilized by multiple O–H⋯O hydrogen bonds ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structural determination of I indicates that it is a 2D coordination polymer. The asymmetric part of the unit cell contains two crystallographically independent centrosymmetric dimeric anions (denoted as A and B, respectively). Two fragments of the crystal structure showing the A and B dimeric units are depicted in   while selected bond lengths are listed in  . The octahedral chromium centre is linked to four donor atoms of the nta 3- ligands (N,O,O,O) and two bridging OH groups. The Cr-N bonds in I are equal to 2.067(5), for A and 2.071(5)Å for B dimers, the Cr-O ones being in the 1.875(4) and 1.956(4)Å range. The coordinated nitrilotriacetic acid forms three five-membered chelate rings (R, G1 and G2) according to Ref. . The Cr⋯Cr separation in A and B dimers are equal to 2.879(2) and 2.888(2)Å, respectively. Dimers A (a) are characterized by four G-carboxylate groups chelating the 10-coordinate Ba ions. Two of them are tridentate-bridging groups (η2:η1:μ2) and two are tetradentate (η2:η2:μ2). In contrast, the B-type dimers (b) contain two trans G-carboxylate bridging groups (η1:η1:μ2). The barium coordination sphere is made of six oxygen atoms coming from four nta 3- ligands and four water molecules ( ). The carboxylate oxygen atom O6 bridges two centrosymmetrically related Ba2+ions, with a Ba⋯Ba separation of 4.855(1)Å. The decadentate dimeric anions (A) lead to the formation of chains along the a axis, while the Cr2-dimers (B) join the adjacent chains into a 2D polymeric structure (), which is additionally stabilized by multiple O-H⋯O hydrogen bonds ().

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The asymmetric part of the unit cell in structure <ce:bold>V</ce:bold> contains one molecular Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mn tri-nuclear complex [Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(2,2′-<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], one bypiridine molecule, and five solvate water molecules. In this case the Cr(III) dimer acts as a monodentate ligand participating to the Mn(II) octahedron through the oxygen atom O6, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric part of the unit cell in structure V contains one molecular Cr2Mn tri-nuclear complex [MnII(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)3Cr2(OH)2(nta)2], one bypiridine molecule, and five solvate water molecules. In this case the Cr(III) dimer acts as a monodentate ligand participating to the Mn(II) octahedron through the oxygen atom O6, as shown in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The Mn atom has a distorted octahedral geometry containing the bridging carboxylate oxygen atom (Mn1–O6 2.236(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), two nitrogen atoms from bipyridine (Mn–N<ce:inf loc="post">av</ce:inf> 2.247<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and three water molecules (Mn–O<ce:italic>w</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">av</ce:inf> 2.161<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl4"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cr1⋯Cr2 distance is equal to 2.98(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while the Cr⋯Mn one is larger, 5.56(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The coordinated bipyridine molecule has a satellite bipyridine molecule associated through π–π stacking interaction with centroid-to-centroid distances of 3.501(5) and 3.597(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. All the components of the structure are combined into a 3D framework through hydrogen bonding ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Mn atom has a distorted octahedral geometry containing the bridging carboxylate oxygen atom (Mn1-O6 2.236(2)Å), two nitrogen atoms from bipyridine (Mn-Nav 2.247Å) and three water molecules (Mn-Ow av 2.161Å) ( ). The Cr1⋯Cr2 distance is equal to 2.98(1)Å, while the Cr⋯Mn one is larger, 5.56(1)Å. The coordinated bipyridine molecule has a satellite bipyridine molecule associated through π-π stacking interaction with centroid-to-centroid distances of 3.501(5) and 3.597(5)Å. All the components of the structure are combined into a 3D framework through hydrogen bonding ().

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The second group of complexes consists in three isostructural compounds <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> which have the common formula [M(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, where M is Ni(II), Zn(II) and Co(II). These compounds present ionic structures made of dimeric [Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions, [M(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations and solvate water molecules linked in a 3D network by multiple hydrogen bonds. The Ni(II), Zn(II) and Co(II) coordination polyhedra are completed by four nitrogen atoms from two <ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic> ligands and two water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>) with similar bond lengths for Co(II) and Ni(II) complexes and larger ones for the Zn(II) complex ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The second group of complexes consists in three isostructural compounds II-IV which have the common formula [M(bpy)2(H2O)2][Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O, where M is Ni(II), Zn(II) and Co(II). These compounds present ionic structures made of dimeric [Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]2- anions, [M(bpy)2(H2O)2]2+ cations and solvate water molecules linked in a 3D network by multiple hydrogen bonds. The Ni(II), Zn(II) and Co(II) coordination polyhedra are completed by four nitrogen atoms from two bpy ligands and two water molecules ( ) with similar bond lengths for Co(II) and Ni(II) complexes and larger ones for the Zn(II) complex ().

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Anions are connected into tapes through hydrogen bonds between the hydroxy groups and the carboxylate oxygen atoms of <ce:italic>nta</ce:italic> molecules O1–H⋯O14 and O2–H⋯O8. These tapes are linked into layers through C–H⋯O interactions (). Cations and water molecules lie between the layers and form O–H⋯O hydrogen bonds stabilizing the 3D network.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Anions are connected into tapes through hydrogen bonds between the hydroxy groups and the carboxylate oxygen atoms of nta molecules O1-H⋯O14 and O2-H⋯O8. These tapes are linked into layers through C-H⋯O interactions (). Cations and water molecules lie between the layers and form O-H⋯O hydrogen bonds stabilizing the 3D network.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> contain analogous asymmetric dinuclear [Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions. The bond lengths and angles are almost the same as those found in previously reported centrosymmetric dimeric anions  and fall in the range 1.941(2)–2.029(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cr–O bonds and 2.054(2)–2.073(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cr–N bonds. Most significant differences in anion’s geometry are observed for compound <ce:bold>V</ce:bold> (). The bridging unit is almost planar for <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>, with mean deviations from the Cr1O1O2Cr2 plane of 0.007<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while larger deviations (0.0268<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) are observed for <ce:bold>V</ce:bold>. The glycinato rings G show significant deviations from planarity. The sums of the endocyclic angles vary between 527.04° and 531.39° for <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> and between 525.48° and 533.56° for <ce:bold>V</ce:bold>. The most strained R chelate ring involves the bridging carboxylate group in <ce:bold>V</ce:bold> (the sum of endocyclic angles is 537.32°). For the other R rings these values vary from 539.25° to 539.76°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compounds II-IV contain analogous asymmetric dinuclear [Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]2- anions. The bond lengths and angles are almost the same as those found in previously reported centrosymmetric dimeric anions  and fall in the range 1.941(2)-2.029(2)Å for Cr-O bonds and 2.054(2)-2.073(3)Å for Cr-N bonds. Most significant differences in anion's geometry are observed for compound V (). The bridging unit is almost planar for II-IV, with mean deviations from the Cr1O1O2Cr2 plane of 0.007Å, while larger deviations (0.0268Å) are observed for V. The glycinato rings G show significant deviations from planarity. The sums of the endocyclic angles vary between 527.04° and 531.39° for II-IV and between 525.48° and 533.56° for V. The most strained R chelate ring involves the bridging carboxylate group in V (the sum of endocyclic angles is 537.32°). For the other R rings these values vary from 539.25° to 539.76°.

elements.clean_text: The magnetic behaviors of compounds I-V have been studied in the 2-300K temperature range. The thermal variations of the χ M T susceptibilities, χ M being the molar susceptibility corrected for diamagnetism, for compounds I-IV are shown in   (see also ). For I, the χ M T value at 300K (2.85cm3 mol-1 K) decreases to 0.0036cm3 mol-1 K at 2K. These curves clearly indicate that an intra dimer antiferromagnetic coupling is operating.

elements.clean_text: Usually, for chromium dimers the appropriate model for obtaining a fairly good agreement between the theoretical and experimental data may include a biquadratic exchange term. The resulting Hamiltonian :  (1)    H   ^   = - 2 J (     S   →     1   ⋅     S   →     2   ) - j (     S   →     1   ⋅     S   →     2     )   2     leads to the following expression:  (2)    χ   d   =   2 N   g   Cr   2     β   2     kT   ⋅   exp [ ( 2 J - 6.5 j ) / kT ] + 5 exp [ ( 6 J - 13.5 j ) / kT ] + 14 exp [ ( 12 J - 9 j ) / kT ]   1 + 3 exp [ ( 2 J - 6.5 j ) / kT ] + 5 exp [ ( 6 J - 13.5 j ) / kT ] + 7 exp [ ( 12 J - 9 j ) / kT ]     where the variable magnetic parameters are now J and j that determinate triplet, quintet, and septet electronic ground states   E   (   3     A   2   "   ) = - 2 J + 6.5 j  ;   E   (   5     A   1   '   ) = - 6 J + 13.5 j  ; and   E   (   7     A   2   "   ) = - 12 J + 9 j  , respectively () (see  ).

</ce:display>where <ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic> is the impurity rate and TIP the temperature independent paramagnetism. The best-fitted curves are plotted in  along with the experimental data. The best-fit parameters obtained for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> are −14.95(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> and 4.91(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:italic>j</ce:italic>, with a <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>j</ce:italic> ratio equal to 3.04, similar to the values found in previously studied di-μ-OH chromium dimers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl5"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Considering the interaction between the dinuclear entities, the susceptibility can be corrected by the molecular field approximation  (Eq. ), where zJ' denotes the intramolecular exchange parameter.  (3)    χ   M   '   =     χ   d     [ 1 - 2   zJ   '     χ   d   / N   g   2     β   2   ]   ( 1 - ρ ) + ρ   N   g   2     β   2     3 kT   S ( S + 1 ) + TIP   where ρ is the impurity rate and TIP the temperature independent paramagnetism. The best-fitted curves are plotted in  along with the experimental data. The best-fit parameters obtained for I are -14.95(8)cm-1 for J and 4.91(6)cm-1 for j, with a J/j ratio equal to 3.04, similar to the values found in previously studied di-μ-OH chromium dimers ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Coordination compounds <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> contain dimeric units of chromium and complex cations, where the central atoms are Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>), Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>) and Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>), respectively. The <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> for complex <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> at room temperature is 2.94<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, as a consequence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the chromium atoms of the dimer unit. The fitting of magnetic data can be performed as in the case of complex <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>. To analyze the magnetic properties of complexes <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> we have taken into account the presence of a paramagnetic effect generated by Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Coordination compounds II-IV contain dimeric units of chromium and complex cations, where the central atoms are Zn2+ (II), Ni2+ (III) and Co2+ (IV), respectively. The χ M T for complex II at room temperature is 2.94cm3 mol-1 K, as a consequence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the chromium atoms of the dimer unit. The fitting of magnetic data can be performed as in the case of complex I. To analyze the magnetic properties of complexes III and IV we have taken into account the presence of a paramagnetic effect generated by Ni2+ or Co2+ ions.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The analysis of EPR spectra (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>) proved the absence of any magnetic interaction between the dimer unit and the associated complex-anion. From EPR spectra we can assume that magnetic interactions between the chromium atoms of the dimer are identical in <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The analysis of EPR spectra ( ) proved the absence of any magnetic interaction between the dimer unit and the associated complex-anion. From EPR spectra we can assume that magnetic interactions between the chromium atoms of the dimer are identical in II-IV compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The temperature dependence of the EPR spectrum for compound (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>) agrees with an antiferromagnetic interaction between chromium ions: from 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K down to 96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K the spectrum intensity increases first and then decreases with further decrease in temperature below 96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of the EPR spectrum for compound (II) agrees with an antiferromagnetic interaction between chromium ions: from 300K down to 96K the spectrum intensity increases first and then decreases with further decrease in temperature below 96K ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Simulation of the spectrum for compound <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> allows an estimation of the fine structure and exchange interaction parameters () ().</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The EPR lines belonging to the Cr dimer units in compound <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> have the same thermal dependence as the isostructural compound <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, except that they are not observed below 39<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. In the 79–39<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K temperature range lines corresponding to the Cr dimer units and to mononuclear cobalt fragments are observed. At <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>⩽<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>26<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>), only the cobalt lines are observed. The absence of broadening and shifts of the Cr lines () confirms there is no exchange interaction between the chromium units and the mononuclear cobalt complexes. This is also true for compound <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Simulation of the spectrum for compound II allows an estimation of the fine structure and exchange interaction parameters () ().

The EPR lines belonging to the Cr dimer units in compound IV have the same thermal dependence as the isostructural compound II, except that they are not observed below 39K. In the 79-39K temperature range lines corresponding to the Cr dimer units and to mononuclear cobalt fragments are observed. At T ⩽26K ( ), only the cobalt lines are observed. The absence of broadening and shifts of the Cr lines () confirms there is no exchange interaction between the chromium units and the mononuclear cobalt complexes. This is also true for compound II.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">It is worth to mention once more that complexes <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> are isostructural, what explains the EPR spectra. Therefore, the total magnetic behaviour for complexes <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> can be represented as a sum of two contributions: one from the dimer unit <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">d</ce:inf> and the second from the monomeric cationic complexes <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3d</ce:inf> so that the total magnetic susceptibility can be presented by the equation:<ce:display>
<ce:formula>
<ce:label>(4)</ce:label>
<mml:math altimg="si11.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msub>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>χ</mml:mi>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>M</mml:mtext>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:msub>
<mml:mo>=</mml:mo>
<mml:msub>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>χ</mml:mi>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>d</mml:mtext>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:msub>
<mml:mo>+</mml:mo>
<mml:msub>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>χ</mml:mi>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>
<mml:mtext>d</mml:mtext>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:msub>
</mml:math>
</ce:formula>
</ce:display>where <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">d</ce:inf> is the magnetic susceptibility of chromium dimers and <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3d</ce:inf> the susceptibility of 3d ions (Ni(II) and Co(II)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is worth to mention once more that complexes II, III and IV are isostructural, what explains the EPR spectra. Therefore, the total magnetic behaviour for complexes III and IV can be represented as a sum of two contributions: one from the dimer unit χ d and the second from the monomeric cationic complexes χ 3d so that the total magnetic susceptibility can be presented by the equation:  (4)    χ   M   =   χ   d   +   χ   3 d     where χ d is the magnetic susceptibility of chromium dimers and χ 3d the susceptibility of 3d ions (Ni(II) and Co(II)).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> for complex <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> is equal to 4.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, (b) which corresponds to the contribution of a chromium dimer (2.94<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K), and one nickel(II) ion in an octahedral environment (<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf> state). At 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value is 0.95<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (b) which corresponds to the contribution of the isolated Ni(II) complex. At room temperature, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> difference between compounds <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> is slightly larger than expected (1.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1). This can be explained by the axial distortion of the Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> octahedral configuration or the presence of a Zero Field Splitting contribution. Generally the magnetism of mononuclear Ni(II) complexes is dominated by zero-field splitting parameters (D) which result from splitting of the <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 manifold state into the <ce:italic>Γ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-singlet (<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">S</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0) and <ce:italic>Γ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-doublet (<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">S</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±1) states . In axial symmetry, the magnetic behavior of monomeric complex ions containing Ni(II) can be represented using the D parameters according to the following equations :<ce:display>

</ce:display>In case of complex <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>, high-spin Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>A<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf>) ions with a spin–orbit contribution are also present in an octahedral coordination geometry. The lowest energy levels of the Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations are <ce:italic>Γ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (referred to <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">S</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±1/2) and <ce:italic>Γ</ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">S</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±3/2) Kramers doublets split by the spin–orbit coupling (). Considering that the coordinated ligands are two molecules of <ce:italic>bipy</ce:italic>, with a strong field ligand (large Δ(10Dq)), we can admit that there are only two lowest Kramers doublets <ce:italic>Γ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>Γ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> arising from the <ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>A<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf> state which are thermally populated. Hence the total susceptibility can be described by :<ce:display>

</ce:display>Due to the fact that complexes <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> are isostructural and that the EPR study results prove the absence of any magnetic interaction between the chromium dimer and the complex cation, we can assume that similar antiferromagnetic interactions are active in the three complexes. In this case the magnetic data for <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> can be fitted simultaneously using as a general variable parameter unique values for <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> and for <ce:italic>j</ce:italic>. A similar multifunctional fitting procedure was applied for a simultaneous fitting of the susceptibility and magnetization data . This strategy allows an accurate estimation of the chromium dimer interaction as well as an accurate estimation of the <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> parameters associated to the cationic monomeric complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The χ M T for complex III is equal to 4.15cm3 mol-1 K, (b) which corresponds to the contribution of a chromium dimer (2.94cm3 mol-1 K), and one nickel(II) ion in an octahedral environment (4 T 1g state). At 2K the χ M T value is 0.95cm3 mol-1 K (b) which corresponds to the contribution of the isolated Ni(II) complex. At room temperature, the χ M T difference between compounds III and II is slightly larger than expected (1.00cm3 mol-1 K for S =1). This can be explained by the axial distortion of the Ni2+ octahedral configuration or the presence of a Zero Field Splitting contribution. Generally the magnetism of mononuclear Ni(II) complexes is dominated by zero-field splitting parameters (D) which result from splitting of the S =1 manifold state into the Γ 4-singlet (M S =0) and Γ 5-doublet (M S =±1) states . In axial symmetry, the magnetic behavior of monomeric complex ions containing Ni(II) can be represented using the D parameters according to the following equations :  (5)    χ   Ni   =   (   χ   z   + 2   χ   ⊥   )   3        (6)         χ   z   =     Ng   Ni   2     β   2     kT   ⋅   2 exp ( - D / kT )   1 + 2 exp ( - D / kT )   ;          χ   ⊥   =     Ng   Ni   2     β   2     kT   ⋅   2 ( kT / D ) [ 1 - exp ( - D / kT ) ]   1 + 2 exp ( - D / kT )         In case of complex IV, high-spin Co2+ (4A2g) ions with a spin-orbit contribution are also present in an octahedral coordination geometry. The lowest energy levels of the Co2+ cations are Γ 6 (referred to M S =±1/2) and Γ 7 (referred to M S =±3/2) Kramers doublets split by the spin-orbit coupling (). Considering that the coordinated ligands are two molecules of bipy, with a strong field ligand (large Δ(10Dq)), we can admit that there are only two lowest Kramers doublets Γ 6 and Γ 7 arising from the 4A2g state which are thermally populated. Hence the total susceptibility can be described by :  (7)    χ   Co ( HS )   =   N   μ   B   2     3 k          g   z   2     χ   z   + 8   g   ⊥   2     χ   ⊥     4 T        where  (8)    χ   z   =   1 + 9   e   - ( 2 D / T )     1 +   e   - ( 2 D / T )      and    χ   ⊥   =   1 + ( 3 T / 4 D ) ( 1 -   e   - ( 2 D / T )   )   1 +   e   - ( 2 D / T )       Due to the fact that complexes II, III and IV are isostructural and that the EPR study results prove the absence of any magnetic interaction between the chromium dimer and the complex cation, we can assume that similar antiferromagnetic interactions are active in the three complexes. In this case the magnetic data for II, III, and IV can be fitted simultaneously using as a general variable parameter unique values for J and for j. A similar multifunctional fitting procedure was applied for a simultaneous fitting of the susceptibility and magnetization data . This strategy allows an accurate estimation of the chromium dimer interaction as well as an accurate estimation of the D M and g M parameters associated to the cationic monomeric complexes.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The fitting results are represented in a graphic form in b while the data are collated in . The values of ZFS parameters for Ni(II) in an octahedral environment are in the range of −<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10 to +10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, especially for [NiN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] chromophore where this value is positive ≈<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 to +11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. In our compound <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> we have obtained a value of +2.56(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, close to similar published compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The fitting results are represented in a graphic form in b while the data are collated in . The values of ZFS parameters for Ni(II) in an octahedral environment are in the range of -10 to +10cm-1, especially for [NiN4O2] chromophore where this value is positive ~+4 to +11cm-1. In our compound III we have obtained a value of +2.56(9)cm-1, close to similar published compounds .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Use of the following Hamiltonian allows fitting of the magnetization data for compound <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> (Cr2Ni) with the <ce:small-caps>anisofit</ce:small-caps>2.0 program  implemented on the <ce:small-caps>matlab</ce:small-caps> platform:<ce:display>
<ce:formula>
<ce:label>(9)</ce:label>
<mml:math altimg="si16.gif" overflow="scroll">

</ce:display>where <ce:italic>β</ce:italic> is the Bohr magneton and <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>E</ce:italic>, <ce:bold>S</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>B</ce:bold> represent the Lande’ <ce:italic>g</ce:italic> factor, the axial and rhombic zero-field splitting parameters, and the spin and magnetic field vectors, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Use of the following Hamiltonian allows fitting of the magnetization data for compound III (Cr2Ni) with the anisofit2.0 program  implemented on the matlab platform:  (9)  H =   DS   z   2   + E (   S   x   2   +   S   y   2   ) +   g   iso   β SB   where β is the Bohr magneton and g, D, E, S, and B represent the Lande' g factor, the axial and rhombic zero-field splitting parameters, and the spin and magnetic field vectors, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The results (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.11, and <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) are very similar to those obtained above (see ). A comparison between experimental data, fitting data and simulation data by Brillion function is given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The results (S =1, g =2.11, and D =2.5cm-1) are very similar to those obtained above (see ). A comparison between experimental data, fitting data and simulation data by Brillion function is given in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">For Co(II) ions in an octahedral environment the <ce:italic>D</ce:italic> values are included in the range of +25 to +83<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
. In our case this value (77(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) is close to the maximum value. The <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>j</ce:italic> values are in concordance with similar di-μ-OH chromium dimers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For Co(II) ions in an octahedral environment the D values are included in the range of +25 to +83cm-1 . In our case this value (77(3)cm-1) is close to the maximum value. The J and j values are in concordance with similar di-μ-OH chromium dimers.

elements.content:

</ce:display>We have numerically simulated a molar magnetic susceptibility <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>, using the following equations :<ce:display>

</ce:display>where <ce:italic>M</ce:italic> is the macroscopic molar magnetization, <ce:italic>H</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> the homogeneous magnetic field, <ce:italic>N</ce:italic> the Avogadro number, <ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> the energy levels of the spin-Hamiltonian , <ce:italic>k</ce:italic> the Boltzmann constant, <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> the temperature, and <ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic> the paramagnetic impurity factor. The fitting results indicate the presence of an antiferromagnetic interaction between the two chromium ions and a ferromagnetic interaction between Cr and Mn ions (). At low temperatures, where a complete coupling of the chromium occurs, the magnetic behaviour is determined by the five uncoupled Mn(II) electrons (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig12"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The complex compound V differs essentially through a coordination bond bridging the Mn(II) and chromium dimer (). To analyze the magnetic properties of this complex we have introduced a supplementary parameter J MnCr1. Therefore, the Hamiltonian can be represented as follows:  (10)  H =   g   Cr   β H (   S   z Cr 1   +   S   z Cr 2   ) +   g   Mn   β   HS   z Mn   - 2   J   Cr 1 Cr 2   (   S   Cr 1     S   Cr 2   ) -   j   Cr 1 Cr 2   (   S   Cr 1     S   Cr 2     )   2   - 2   J   MnCr 1   (   S   Mn     S   Cr 1   )   We have numerically simulated a molar magnetic susceptibility χ, using the following equations :  (11)         χ   M   '   =   ∂ M   ∂ H   ( 1 - ρ ) + ρ     Ng   2     β   2     3 kT   S ( S + 1 ) + TIP        M =   N   ∑   n   ( - ∂   E   n   / ∂   H   0   ) exp ( -   E   n   / kT )     ∑   n   exp ( -   E   n   / kT )         where M is the macroscopic molar magnetization, H 0 the homogeneous magnetic field, N the Avogadro number, E  n  the energy levels of the spin-Hamiltonian , k the Boltzmann constant, T the temperature, and ρ the paramagnetic impurity factor. The fitting results indicate the presence of an antiferromagnetic interaction between the two chromium ions and a ferromagnetic interaction between Cr and Mn ions (). At low temperatures, where a complete coupling of the chromium occurs, the magnetic behaviour is determined by the five uncoupled Mn(II) electrons ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">EPR spectra are determined by transitions between sublevels in the states of the chromium dimers (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2,<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3).</ce:para><ce:para view="all">It is expected that for chromium dimers the EPR spectrum is a sum of spectra coming from <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2, and 3 pair-states, their contributions being dependent on the temperature and isotropic exchange. Positions of transitions in pair- states depend on the splitting of these states which are determined by the Zeeman energy, dipole–dipole and anisotropy exchange interactions between chromium ions, and the fine structure of chromium ions:<ce:display>
<ce:formula>
<ce:label>(12)</ce:label>
<mml:math altimg="si19.gif" overflow="scroll">

elements.clean_text:
EPR spectra are determined by transitions between sublevels in the states of the chromium dimers (S =1,2,3).

It is expected that for chromium dimers the EPR spectrum is a sum of spectra coming from S =1,2, and 3 pair-states, their contributions being dependent on the temperature and isotropic exchange. Positions of transitions in pair- states depend on the splitting of these states which are determined by the Zeeman energy, dipole-dipole and anisotropy exchange interactions between chromium ions, and the fine structure of chromium ions:  (12)  H = g (   S   Cr 1   +   S   Cr 2   ) +   g   2     b   2     r   - 3   {   S   Cr 1     S   Cr 2   - 3   r   - 2   (   S   Cr 1   r ) (   S   Cr 2   r ) } - 2   J   Cr 1 Cr 2   (   S   Cr 1     S   Cr 2   ) +   ∑   j = 1 , 2      D      S   z Cr i   2   -   1   3   S ( S + 1 )    + E (   S   x Cr i   2   -   S   y Cr i   2   )      where J Cr1Cr2 is the tensor of exchange interaction, which includes isotropic and anisotropic contributions, r the radius-vector between chromium ions. D and E are parameters of the fine structure.

elements.clean_text: A wide signal (ΔH =800Oe) with a g-factor close to two is detected in the spectra of compound V in X- and Q-bands at room temperature ( a). As the temperature decreases the fine structure of spectrum is resolved. At T =4.2K this signal is split on five components and an additional signal in the half field region is detected (b). It is clear that the lines characteristic of the chromium dimer unit are not detected.

elements.clean_text: The energy levels order is determined by the ∣J Cr1Mn∣/∣J Cr1Cr2∣ ratio. In the case of an antiferromagnetic interaction between chromium ions with ∣J Cr1Cr2∣>∣J Cr1 Mn∣, the ground state of the cluster is the state with S =5/2 and S 12 =0 and the low temperature spectra mainly correspond to the S =5/2 state, with only small contributions from the excited states. In the absence of Mn-Cr interaction a spectrum characteristic of a manganese ion with S =5/2 is expected if the chromium dimer is in the S =0 state. The simulations of the 4.2K spectrum with the two models are very close ( ). Furthermore, an EPR spectrum taken at 42K does not bring significative changes in the ratio intensities of the different lines but it appears that the best fit is then obtained with the J parameters deduced from the magnetic study (). This result and the absence of signals coming from the chromium dimer unit at O~45-70K plays in favor of Cr-Mn interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The synthesis of a “magnetic brick” containing dinuclear chromium units [Ba(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ- OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>) has allowed the preparation of four heterometallic compounds with formulae [M(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with M<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Zn, (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>); Ni, (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>); Co, (<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>) and [Mn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>V</ce:bold>) (<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-bipyridine, <ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nitrilotriacetate ion). Complex <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> represents a 2D polymer formed by coordination of centrosymmetrical dimeric chromium(III) units and Ba atoms. The X-ray data show that the Ba atom was 10-coordinated by four water molecules and six different oxygen atoms from two different centrosymmetrical chromium(III) dimers. Compounds <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> are isostructural and consist of non-centrosymmetric dimeric anions [Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, complex cations [M<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and solvate water molecules. Multiple hydrogen bonds of coordinated and solvate water molecules link the anions and cations in a 3D network. The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>V</ce:bold> were fitted on the basis of the expression derived from an isotropic Hamiltonian including a bi-quadratic exchange term. The analysis of EPR spectra for <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> proved the absence of any magnetic interaction between the chromium dimers [Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and the associated complex-anions [M<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. In complexes <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> the measured magnetic susceptibilities correspond to the sum of the two contributions: the first one from the dimeric Cr units <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">d</ce:inf> and the second one from the monomeric cation. Applying the simultaneous fitting procedure with common variables, the magnetic interaction between Cr (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>j</ce:italic>) atoms and the Zero Field Splitting parameters for Co(II) and Ni(II) have been estimated. Typical values characteristic for Co(II) and Ni(II) ions in octahedral N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> environments have been found. Although a similar [Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> unit is found in <ce:bold>V</ce:bold>, a carboxylate oxygen atom of the <ce:italic>nta</ce:italic> ligand makes a bridge that leads to the formation of a trinuclear complex [Mn(<ce:italic>bpy</ce:italic>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. A fitting of the magnetic data agrees with the presence of an antiferromagnetic interaction between chromium atoms and a ferromagnetic Cr1–Mn(II) interaction. An analysis of its EPR spectra with the help of calculated spectra confirms the presence of weak Mn–Cr interactions in <ce:bold>V</ce:bold> which are comparable to the data deduced from the magnetic study.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The synthesis of a "magnetic brick" containing dinuclear chromium units [Ba(H2O)4Cr2(μ- OH)2(nta)2]⋅3H2O (I) has allowed the preparation of four heterometallic compounds with formulae [M(bpy)2(H2O)2][Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O with M2+ =Zn, (II); Ni, (III); Co, (IV) and [Mn(H2O)3(bpy)Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅(bpy)⋅5H2O (V) (bpy =2,2'-bipyridine, nta =nitrilotriacetate ion). Complex I represents a 2D polymer formed by coordination of centrosymmetrical dimeric chromium(III) units and Ba atoms. The X-ray data show that the Ba atom was 10-coordinated by four water molecules and six different oxygen atoms from two different centrosymmetrical chromium(III) dimers. Compounds II-IV are isostructural and consist of non-centrosymmetric dimeric anions [Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]2-, complex cations [MII(bpy)2(H2O)2]2+ and solvate water molecules. Multiple hydrogen bonds of coordinated and solvate water molecules link the anions and cations in a 3D network. The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities for I-V were fitted on the basis of the expression derived from an isotropic Hamiltonian including a bi-quadratic exchange term. The analysis of EPR spectra for II-IV proved the absence of any magnetic interaction between the chromium dimers [Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]2- and the associated complex-anions [MII(bpy)2(H2O)2]2+. In complexes II, III and IV the measured magnetic susceptibilities correspond to the sum of the two contributions: the first one from the dimeric Cr units χ d and the second one from the monomeric cation. Applying the simultaneous fitting procedure with common variables, the magnetic interaction between Cr (J and j) atoms and the Zero Field Splitting parameters for Co(II) and Ni(II) have been estimated. Typical values characteristic for Co(II) and Ni(II) ions in octahedral N4O2 environments have been found. Although a similar [Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]2- unit is found in V, a carboxylate oxygen atom of the nta ligand makes a bridge that leads to the formation of a trinuclear complex [Mn(bpy)(H2O)2Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]. A fitting of the magnetic data agrees with the presence of an antiferromagnetic interaction between chromium atoms and a ferromagnetic Cr1-Mn(II) interaction. An analysis of its EPR spectra with the help of calculated spectra confirms the presence of weak Mn-Cr interactions in V which are comparable to the data deduced from the magnetic study.

Supplementary material

CCDC 654575, 654576, 654577, 654578 and 654579 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.ica.2007.10.014.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) dissolved in 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of water was added to the initial solution, the temperature being maintained at about 95<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Neutralisation of the reaction mixture (pH 6.5–7) was carried out with concentrated NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>OH. The solution changed from violet to navy blue-green. The reaction mixture was filtered off and concentrated to 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL. <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.28<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>α</ce:italic>′-bipyridyl (0.32<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were dissolved in 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of water. After addition of crystalline BaCr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>nta</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.76<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) the resulting solution was warmed up to 40–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Then the cold solution was filtered to eliminate BaSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and concentrated to 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL. Details of IR spectra and analytical data are reported in the .</ce:para>

Synthesis

[Barium-di-μ-hydroxy-bis-(nitrilotriacetatochromium(III))]heptahydrate [Ba(H2O)4Cr2(μ-OH)2(nta)2]⋅3H2O (I)

Water (100mL) was added to a mixture of H 3 nta (0.76g, 4mmol) and dispersed BaCO3 (1.18g, 6mmol). The resulting solution was warmed up to 95°C. After complete dissolution of BaCO3, CrCl3 ⋅6H2O (1.07g, 4mmol) dissolved in 50mL of water was added to the initial solution, the temperature being maintained at about 95°C. Neutralisation of the reaction mixture (pH 6.5-7) was carried out with concentrated NH4OH. The solution changed from violet to navy blue-green. The reaction mixture was filtered off and concentrated to 30mL. Twenty-four hours later, the blue-violet crystals were separated by filtration, washed with cold water, ethanol and ether. Yield: 95%.

[Di-(α,α'-bipyridyl)-diaqua-zinc] [di-μ-hydroxy-bis-(nitrilotriacetatochromate(III))heptahydrate, [Zn(bpy)2(H2O)2] [Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O (II)

ZnSO4 ⋅7H2O (0.28g, 1mmol) and α,α'-bipyridyl (0.32g, 2mmol) were dissolved in 30mL of water. After addition of crystalline BaCr2(nta)2(OH)2 ⋅7H2O (0.76g, 1mmol) the resulting solution was warmed up to 40-50°C. Then the cold solution was filtered to eliminate BaSO4 and concentrated to 20mL. Twenty-four hours later the violet crystals that appeared were separated by filtration, washed with cold water, ethanol and diethyl ether. Yield: 62%. The syntheses of [Ni(bpy)2(H2O)2][Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O (III), [Co(bpy)2(H2O)2][Cr2(OH)2(nta)2]⋅7H2O (IV), [Mn(H2O)3(bpy)Cr2(OH)2(nta)2](bpy)⋅5H2O (V) compounds are analogous to that described for II. Details of IR spectra and analytical data are reported in the .

<ce:para view="all">The magnetic behaviors of compounds <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>V</ce:bold> have been studied in the 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K temperature range. The thermal variations of the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> susceptibilities, <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> being the molar susceptibility corrected for diamagnetism, for compounds <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor> (see also ). For <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (2.85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) decreases to 0.0036<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. These curves clearly indicate that an intra dimer antiferromagnetic coupling is operating.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Considering the interaction between the dinuclear entities, the susceptibility can be corrected by the molecular field approximation  (Eq. ), where <ce:italic>zJ</ce:italic>′ denotes the intramolecular exchange parameter.<ce:display>
<ce:formula id="fd1">

</ce:display>where <ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic> is the impurity rate and TIP the temperature independent paramagnetism. The best-fitted curves are plotted in  along with the experimental data. The best-fit parameters obtained for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> are −14.95(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> and 4.91(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:italic>j</ce:italic>, with a <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>j</ce:italic> ratio equal to 3.04, similar to the values found in previously studied di-μ-OH chromium dimers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl5"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Coordination compounds <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> contain dimeric units of chromium and complex cations, where the central atoms are Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>), Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>) and Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>IV</ce:bold>), respectively. The <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> for complex <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> at room temperature is 2.94<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, as a consequence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the chromium atoms of the dimer unit. The fitting of magnetic data can be performed as in the case of complex <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>. To analyze the magnetic properties of complexes <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>IV</ce:bold> we have taken into account the presence of a paramagnetic effect generated by Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The fitting results are represented in a graphic form in b while the data are collated in . The values of ZFS parameters for Ni(II) in an octahedral environment are in the range of −<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10 to +10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, especially for [NiN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] chromophore where this value is positive ≈<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 to +11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. In our compound <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> we have obtained a value of +2.56(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, close to similar published compounds .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The results (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.11, and <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) are very similar to those obtained above (see ). A comparison between experimental data, fitting data and simulation data by Brillion function is given in

. In our case this value (77(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) is close to the maximum value. The <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>j</ce:italic> values are in concordance with similar di-μ-OH chromium dimers.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">A wide signal (Δ<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>a). As the temperature decreases the fine structure of spectrum is resolved. At <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K this signal is split on five components and an additional signal in the half field region is detected (b). It is clear that the lines characteristic of the chromium dimer unit are not detected.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
The magnetic behaviors of compounds I-V have been studied in the 2-300K temperature range. The thermal variations of the χ M T susceptibilities, χ M being the molar susceptibility corrected for diamagnetism, for compounds I-IV are shown in   (see also ). For I, the χ M T value at 300K (2.85cm3 mol-1 K) decreases to 0.0036cm3 mol-1 K at 2K. These curves clearly indicate that an intra dimer antiferromagnetic coupling is operating.

Considering the interaction between the dinuclear entities, the susceptibility can be corrected by the molecular field approximation  (Eq. ), where zJ' denotes the intramolecular exchange parameter.  (3)    χ   M   '   =     χ   d     [ 1 - 2   zJ   '     χ   d   / N   g   2     β   2   ]   ( 1 - ρ ) + ρ   N   g   2     β   2     3 kT   S ( S + 1 ) + TIP   where ρ is the impurity rate and TIP the temperature independent paramagnetism. The best-fitted curves are plotted in  along with the experimental data. The best-fit parameters obtained for I are -14.95(8)cm-1 for J and 4.91(6)cm-1 for j, with a J/j ratio equal to 3.04, similar to the values found in previously studied di-μ-OH chromium dimers ( ).

Coordination compounds II-IV contain dimeric units of chromium and complex cations, where the central atoms are Zn2+ (II), Ni2+ (III) and Co2+ (IV), respectively. The χ M T for complex II at room temperature is 2.94cm3 mol-1 K, as a consequence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the chromium atoms of the dimer unit. The fitting of magnetic data can be performed as in the case of complex I. To analyze the magnetic properties of complexes III and IV we have taken into account the presence of a paramagnetic effect generated by Ni2+ or Co2+ ions.

The fitting results are represented in a graphic form in b while the data are collated in . The values of ZFS parameters for Ni(II) in an octahedral environment are in the range of -10 to +10cm-1, especially for [NiN4O2] chromophore where this value is positive ~+4 to +11cm-1. In our compound III we have obtained a value of +2.56(9)cm-1, close to similar published compounds .

The results (S =1, g =2.11, and D =2.5cm-1) are very similar to those obtained above (see ). A comparison between experimental data, fitting data and simulation data by Brillion function is given in  .

For Co(II) ions in an octahedral environment the D values are included in the range of +25 to +83cm-1 . In our case this value (77(3)cm-1) is close to the maximum value. The J and j values are in concordance with similar di-μ-OH chromium dimers.

A wide signal (ΔH =800Oe) with a g-factor close to two is detected in the spectra of compound V in X- and Q-bands at room temperature ( a). As the temperature decreases the fine structure of spectrum is resolved. At T =4.2K this signal is split on five components and an additional signal in the half field region is detected (b). It is clear that the lines characteristic of the chromium dimer unit are not detected.

cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 10  (a) EPR spectrum of a polycrystalline sample of compound V (X-band) at T =4.2K; (b) simulated spectrum for S =5/2, g =1.985, D =0.01375cm-1, and E =0.0045cm-1; (c) simulated EPR spectra for three interacting spins with S =3/2, 3/2 and 5/2. For S =3/2: D =-0.205cm-1, and J Cr1Cr2 =-15.84cm-1; for S 3 =5/2: D =0.015cm-1, and E =0.005cm-1; J Cr1Mn =4.67cm-1, and parameters of anisotropic exchange interaction between Cr and Mn ions (J  xx  S 1x  S 2x  + J  yy  S 1y  S 2y  + J  zz  S 1z  S 2z ): J  xx  =-0.0174cm-1, J  yy  =0.0087cm-1, and J  zz  =0.0087cm-1.
